GAVEL...AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL...HOUSEWIVES OF WHATEVER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small economy CAR proceeds down the street. Driving aro a kiddy park and public swimming pool with kids in the background. The PLACARD mounted on top says "WINDSOR DRIV SCHOOL." We hear a man's voice, with a soft East Indian accent.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Make a left. EXT. DRIVING TEST SITE вЂ”- STUDENT CAR вЂ”- LATE AFTERNO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON SIGNAL LEVER - A BOY'S HAND pushes it down. STEERING WHEEL - BOYS' HANDS turn it counterclockwise.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Slow down. Execute a three-point turn. THE CAR stops, makes a careful U-Turn. POV THROUGH WINDSHIELD - approaching a line of parked car man's FINGER enters frame, pointing to an empty space. MAN (0.S.) (cont'd) Park there. THE CAR slides expertly into the space. PASSENGER POV - DOOR OPENS, we see the distance to the cu six inches. Perfect. NEW ANGLE - Now we see the car's occupants. At the wheel, 16-year-old BOY who looks 12. Beside him: a Sikh man, sti handsome in his mid-50's, full beard and sky-blue turban. holds himself erect and formal, wears a freshly ironed sh and tie. He would seem severe if not for his great warm, brown eyes. This is DARWAN SINGH.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Yampolsky, you have followed all the rules. You will pass your test tomorrow, I am sure of it. The boy DRUMS on the wheel, mimes dancing in his seat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) (gentle but firm) And after you get your license, I suspect you will buy the biggest, fastest car...and throw all the rules out the window. (boy grins) It's not a joke. Remember, driving is a freedom. I wish you to enjoy every kind of freedom, as long you don't hurt someone. So follow the rules. Will you promise me?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Okay, Mr. Singh. EXT. WINDSOR DRIVING SCHOOL - LATER вЂ”- MAGIC HOUR Darwan parks the student car alongside others like it, be the Windsor School storefront. He gets out, drops the key a locked box. INT. WINDSOR DRIVING SCHOOL - MINUTES LATER вЂ” MAGIC HOU

dialogues.speaker: TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: We're watching a driving instruction film made in the 60' man (HAROLD SMITH) drives a wide convertible down a boule in L.A. He reviews the five principles of safe driving as they flash across the screen:

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD SMITH
dialogues.text: One: Aim High In Steering. Two: Get the Big Picture. Three: Keep Your Eyes Moving. ANOTHER ANGLE - we're in a small classroom, where Darwan' BOSS is teaching Drivers Ed. Watching the film are a HOUSEWIFE, a couple of TEENAGERS, two IMMIGRANT MEN. Darwan sticks his head in the room. His boss comes to the rear of the classroom where he hands Darwan his paycheck. HAROLD SMITH (0.S.) (cont'd) Four: Leave Yourself An Out. Five: Make Sure They See You.  8/21/13 3. EXT. TAXI COMPANY - LATER вЂ” NIGHT TAXI DRIVERS gas up their CABS at a pump beside the garag Darwan takes over a CAB from another driver ending his sh EXT. TAXI - A LITTLE LATER вЂ” NIGHT Darwan stands outside of his cab, finishing his supper of fritters and puffed bread from an Indian deli. A radio station plays INDIAN POP MUSIC. A KHANDA, a Sikh talisman hangs from the rear view mirror. ANGLE ON HIS ID CARD mounted on the Plexiglass barrier be his head. We see his PHOTO and the name "SINGH, DARWAN." WIDE EXTERIOR - Darwan's cab is parked near the entrance the QUEENSBOROUGH BRIDGE where he can see the always-вЂ” spectacular NIGHT SKYLINE OF MANHATTAN. The "ON DUTY" SIGN on top of Darwan's cab LIGHTS UP. He p the taxi out and joins the line of CARS inching up to the bridge. Close in on the cabs rooftop sign going on and off continuously, driving around the city. (As if picking up dropping off passengers. Until... EXT. STREET, EAST SIDE - LATER вЂ” NIGHT MAN tears out of an upscale restaurant, his arm up. Darwan stops. The man (TED) jumps in the back, SLAMMING t door. INT. TAXI вЂ” CONTINUOUS - NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Hudson and Jane! Quick! Darwan throws the meter, touches his foot to the accelera when the REAR DOOR FLINGS OPEN again. A Woman (WENDY) hur herself onto the seat next to Ted. Both are in their 40's

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How dare you run out on me!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You threw a bottle at me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Darwan drives on, checking his rear mirror nervously. The woman's face is contorted with anger; the man is stoic.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Brilliant maneuver! Inform me our marriage is over, in a public restaurant, so I can't make a scene -- and you thought that would work?! I wish my aim was better, you bastard --- Her arm swoops out to hit him; he catches her wrist, thro her back. DARWAN tries to distract them, to defuse the fireworks.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, you said Hudson and Jane Street?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Ted) Is that where she lives? You cocksucker!

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I'm not going home with you. The woman's fury gives way to tears.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Why? Why? You can't just -- twenty- one years, Ted! How long have you been lying to me?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I didn't lie.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No, you just didn't say anything, so how could I possibly know anything was wrong, and now you blindside me -- Ted turns to her, his voice thick with rage, shaking his finger in her face.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Blindside?! When do you ever notice anything, Wendy? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TED (cont'd) On that rare occasion when you look up from your books or your fucking computer, you look right through me! I felt like a ghost!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm seeing through you now and you're a prick! (more sobs; then: ) What is she, one of your students? He looks out the window, ignoring her. WENDY (cont'd) That's as good as a yes. Bet you "supervised her orals"! Bet she was on her knees for that! God damn you -- She swings again, and WHOP! connects this time with his e He lets out a YELP, pushes her away, fending off her blow DARWAN'S EYES widen in the rear mirror, watching them struggle. Ted breaks away, shouting to the driver:

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Pull over! Let me out here! As the cab slows, Wendy clings to Ted.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Please! Ted! Come home, we'll talk--

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It won't do any good.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't understand -- why? Why? The taxi stops near the curb. Ted is out the door, SLAMMING it firmly. He thrusts cash Darwan through the window.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Take her to 600 West 98th. Wendy throws open the door again to follow him. Ted pushe closed, blocking it with his body as he calls to Darwan: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: TED (cont'd) Go! Go! Darwan pulls the taxi away quickly. The momentum bounces back on the cushion, where she lets out a long, wounded W Darwan maintains a pained silence as he drives the woman home. He glances now and then in the rear mirror to see h crumpled up and SOBBING without restraint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan pulls up in front of a narrow three-story brownsto

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: We are here. Number six hundred. Wendy stuffs a twenty in his tray and gets out. Her face obscured but he can tell she's crying. As she stumbles to door, Darwan jumps out with the money. DARWAN (cont'd) No, please. He paid me already -- But Wendy is already inside, and the door SLAMS shut. INT. FRONT HALL - WENDY'S HOUSE вЂ”- CONTINUOUS - NIGHT 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy flicks on the LIGHT and stands numbly in the hall. get a better look at her. Fierce eyes in a soft, vulnerab face. Attractive but careless about her looks. The hallway is lined with bookcases. Piles of messengered books and mail are on the hall table, and a bowl full of and coins. Seen through an open door, the living room is of dusty Danish-modern furniture, and like the hall is cluttered with books, on shelves and on every surface. Wendy's eyes fall to the two tennis racquets leaning agai the wall. They lift to the framed PHOTO of her with Ted, little girl (TASHA) between them, laughing on top of some mountain. She shakes her head in mute disbelief. She walks mechanically to the coat closet. Removing her jacket, she hangs it up, then pauses at the sight of the empty hanger for his coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens the door, steps in, and stares at the bed. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WENDY'S POV (FANTASY) - Ted lounges in bed, wearing an ol shirt, grading test papers. He doesn't look up. RUNNING W O.S.... WE PAN TO THE OPEN BATHROOM DOOR. Ted's in there, back to her, bare butt peeking from under the torn t-shir brushing his teeth, the faucet running.... FOOTSTEPS BEHI HER O.S. WENDY turns toward the sound, in the doorway. WENDY'S POV - Ted's going downstairs, into the darkness.. beat...The front door CLOSES WITH A LOUD REPORT -- -- shattering her fantasy. She starts to hyperventilate, gasping for breath. Then she rushes past the empty bed, i the empty bathroom. We hear her VOMITING into the toilet. EXT. TAXI COMPANY - LATER вЂ” PRE-DAWN 12 Back in Queens, Darwan returns the taxi. He removes his belongings, and checks the rear seat. He sees a PADDED ENVELOPE ON THE FLOOR. One of his passengers must have le something. There is no name on the outside of the envelope. The flap open. He slips his hand in and pulls out a new HARDCOVER BOOK. A letter is clipped to the dustcover. We SKIM DOWN the letter as he reads. The letterhead is a publisher, addressed to a WENDY SHIELDS, The New Yorker, "Enclosed is a copy of BEATITUDES for your review...." an editor's sticky note on top reads: "Messenger to 600 West st."

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 13
dialogues.text: EXT. STREET, RICHMOND HILL вЂ”- LATER вЂ” EARLY A.M. 14 The envelope tucked under his arm, Darwan walks wearily u residential street; past small, drab one-family homes bui in the 30's. Only a few other people are on the street th early, all bearded MEN in turbans like Darwan, jackets ov long shirts: this is the Punjabi Sikh neighborhood in Que Darwan enters the basement apartment of a two-story clapb house, unpainted in a decade.  15 8/21/13 8. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ”- MINUTES LATER вЂ” EARLY A.M. We TRACK WITH DARWAN through the one-bedroom apartment. H passes the open bathroom door where a SIKH MAN, barechest from his shower, winds his turban around his long hair wh is knotted on top of his head. Darwan glances inside a tiny bedroom, where ANOTHER SIKH is asleep in the one bed. Darwan's 23-year-old nephew PRE dressed in construction clothes, is rolling up his mattre on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (WHISPERS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Preet. The boy doesn't hear at first, his ears blocked by the earbuds from the iPod in his pocket. DARWAN (cont'd) Preet! Preet looks up, smiling sheepishly as he pulls out the earbuds. He joins Darwan in the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: Hey. I got another job. Big renovation, four weeks вЂ”

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (interrupts; re: iPod) Where did you get that?

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: I paid for it.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Preet, you must save your money.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: (grins) Uncle D, no. I must have music.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: And turn that around. Darwan is referring to Preet's head wrap which is knotted the back gangsta-style. DARWAN (cont'd) If you can't wear it properly, then put on the dastaar. [turban] (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Preet wags his finger playfully under Darwan's nose.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: Uncle D, it's past your bedtime. Darwan has to smile. He raps his knuckle on Preet's head lets him go. As Preet exits for work, Darwan proceeds into the living room, where a THIRD SIKH MAN is rising from his bed on th couch. Too tired to talk, Darwan nods at him, taking his place on the couch while the other man pads, yawning, to bathroom. Darwan PLACES THE PADDED ENVELOPE CAREFULLY ON THE TEA TA then burrows under the blanket. Darwan then starts unravelling his turban. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: INT. NPR RADIO STUDIO вЂ” DAY 16A An ENGINEER makes last minute adjustments to LAVALIER MIC a public radio HOST (50's) and his three guests: HOWARD ( ROSE (55) and WENDY, all seated at a round table. Wendy has made an attempt to pull herself together, but s seems harried and unfocussed. Self-medication: a very tal takeout container of COFFEE she's downing. The Engineer exits to the glass control BOOTH. Rose leans over to whisper to Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: I heard about you and Ted. I'm really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (recoils) You heard what, exactly?

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (on the spot) Well - that you -

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We're just taking a breather, for God's sake.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (over squawkbox) Standby. The Engineer signals the Host to begin.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: Joining me for today's topic "Are Critics Necessary?" are three columnists from the New Yorker: film critic Howard Mintz, art critic Rose Belknap, and Wendy Shields, who reviews books. Let's start with Wendy. No child dreams of becoming a literary critic, so what led you to it?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I wanted anything to do with words. I grew up in a house that was far from peaceful, and books just... (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WENDY (cont'd) floated me away. ItвЂ™s part of my job to read bad books, too, but the great ones still carry me off.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: What current authors do you enjoy reviewing?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, Martin Amis, Toni Morrison, uh...Delia Krauss - Suddenly the other guests go tense, exchanging alarmed glances; Rose looks dumbfounded. WENDY (CONTвЂ™D) (contвЂ™d) - I especially love her short stories. The magazine publishes most of them - Wendy notices the othersвЂ™ reactions. She laughs uncerta WENDY (CONTвЂ™D) (contвЂ™d) What, nobody likes Delia Krauss? INT. ELEVATOR BANK вЂ”- LATER вЂ” DAY 16B ANGLE ON WENDY AND ROSE waiting for the elevator, backs t camera.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: DeeDee Krauss?! That whore?!

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: We thought you knew.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I thought it was one of TedвЂ™s students. Now I get it. She was Writer-in-Residence last year. (fake-laughing) She plowed through half the faculty. We all said DeeDee Krauss would fuck gravel.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: Maybe it wonвЂ™t last. HeвЂ™1ll come back. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Remind me to change the locks. God, every time I open up the magazine IвЂ™m going to see her name - DING: an elevator arrives. Rose leaves frame to catch it.

dialogues.speaker: ROSE
dialogues.text: (over her shoulder) Are you heading to the office? ANGLE ON WENDY - she doesnвЂ™t respond for a half-beat, r to the spot, as the shock enters her heart.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (distantly) No, IвЂ™m going to work at home...for a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy sits in an easy chair, humped over a book, rapidly reading and making notes. There are stacks of review book everywhere. It's dark and hermetic; her computer SCREEN G on the desk, amid coffee-stained mugs, plates with food crumbs.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mom? Wendy looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy comes down the stairs. Her daughter (TASHA, 19) sta at the bottom, having just let herself in.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Tasha!

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Hi, Mom. Wendy embraces her daughter. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I didn't expect you so early, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Have you got any quarters? I have to feed the meter. Wendy digs in the bowl on the hall table for change.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You must have had a long drive.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Five hours. Fantastic weather. I listened to Vampire Weekend the whole way.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (giving her quarters) Ugh, not one of those stupid paranormal books.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a band. You're such a ditz. INT. KITCHEN, WENDY'S HOUSE - LATER вЂ”- DAY 19 The counters are cluttered with takeout cartons and dirty dishes. As her daughter chatters, Wendy washes out two mu while the water kettle heats up.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: They don't use any chemical sprays or fertilizers. I love being up in the tractor, I love the air and the smells, I love dirt. Growing up in the city I always thought dirt was, like, grime. But their dirt is alive, you know, it's rich, it's nourishing --I just want to eat it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Nostalgie de boue, is what the French say.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: (rolls her eyes) Whatever. I want to skip the fall semester so I can stay for harvest. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Did you ask your father? The question hangs there. The kettle WHISTLES. Wendy make move, as if she doesn't hear it. Finally Tasha turns off fire. The WHISTLE DIES. Tasha pours water in the mugs.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: He said to ask you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Stands to reason, seeing I'm the one paying your tuition. Well, do as you like. Vermont suits you. You look dangerously healthy.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Mom, come stay with me. They'll put you up on the farm. It's a great place to write.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: The train's clear over on the other side of the state, and I can't very well drive up without a license.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: So get one!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Tasha, please letвЂ™s not get into that, not again, not now.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: But don't you want to get away? There's so many memories in this house -- Tasha's voice catches. Her eyes fill up with tears.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Baby... Wendy puts her arms around her daughter, stroking her bac WENDY (cont'd) Why are you crying?

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: When I think of you and Dad not together, it's so sad. And you're here all alone -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: But I'm fine. Tasha sniffs back tears. Wendy absently hands her a crump napkin with traces of duck sauce from the table.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: (pushes it away) Eew.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Please don't be so upset.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: I thought you'd be upset. Wendy sets a tray as she breezily dismisses Tasha's conce

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We've weathered this before. Every seven years, the itch comes over him. He gets restless, does something juvenile. So, at twenty- one years, we're on our third itch. Or it's male menopause. Instead of buying a a motorcycle, Daddy decided to give adultery a spin. As she heads into the living room with the tray: WENDY (cont'd) Tell you what, when he comes home, we'll drive up to visit you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The living room is as dark as the study, the couch covere with newspapers, the coffee table with unopened mail and dirty plates. Arranging the tray on the table, Wendy sits but Tasha remains standing.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Mom...Dad's not coming home.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Look around. He didn't take his books. What does that tell you?

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: He said he filed for a separation already. (CONTINUED)
20 Wendy covers her shock by pouring tea.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: And he uses you to deliver that message? Nice of him to manipulate you. She sips her tea but it burns her tongue. She BANGS her m down and erupts. Beat. WENDY (cont'd) I hope she knows she'll have to pay for his keep. Because he is a loser. In twenty years he couldn't get tenure. How anyone besides me could consider him romantic material is stupefying.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: So you are upset.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No I'm not. I'm disgusted. WENDY (cont'd) You're staying for dinner?

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Actually, I said I'd eat with Dad.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (fury rising again) So this is just a visit. You're popping by to see if Mom's a basket case? And then run that message back to him? Thanks. You can go now. Wendy gets off the couch, striding to the door.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Mom -- ?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I mean it. I have work to do.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: I just got here -- (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (exits) Leave me alone. Tasha is left staring in disbelief. 0.S. Wendy's study DO SLAMS. INT. STUDY - WENDY'S HOUSE - SECONDS LATER вЂ” DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy heaves back in her armchair, snapping open a book. she hears the FRONT DOOR CLOSE O.S. Tasha has left. Wendy's pride deflates: She lets the book slide to the fl and covers her face in her hands. INT. INT. WENDY'S BEDROOM вЂ” ANOTHER DAY Still in her bathrobe, Wendy is face down on the bedcover passed out. There are open WINE BOTTLES AND A SMUDGED GLA on the night table. The DOORBELL rings 0.S.: DING-DONG. INT. FRONT HALL вЂ”- MINUTES LATER вЂ” DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hair matted, bathrobe askew, Wendy opens the door. She pe blearily at the solemn bearded man in a scarlet turban on doorstep. He hands her a padded envelope.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You left this in my cab.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. Just a minute. She puts the envelope on the pile of books on the table, brings the change bowl to the door, scooping a handful of change to give to him. She stops, seeing his look of dism WENDY (cont'd) What am I doing? That's pathetic. (replaces bowl) Let me get you some real money.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I don't want anything. I like to help. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (laughs mirthlessly) You like to help? That's impossible. You can't be from New York.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Yes, I am. From Queens.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That's not New York. But you're very nice, and I thank you. Are you sure I can't give you something? He shakes his head, bowing slightly, his palms together. he turns, heading back to the car double-parked in front her house. More awake now, she focusses for the first tim the placard mounted on his car: "WINDSOR DRIVING SCHOOL." EXT. STUDENT CAR вЂ” CONTINUOUS - DAY 24 He buckles his seat belt and STARTS THE CAR. Suddenly, sh there at the window. He rolls it down.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Do you have a card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy talks on the phone to Tasha. She has DARWAN'S CARD her hand.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Baby, I'm sorry for what I said. You're right, I need a change of scenery. So guess what? I'm going to get my license, buy a car, and drive up to see you, sweetie. And we'll eat some dirt together, OK? INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT -вЂ” NIGHT 26 Darwan sits alongside Preet and two of his ROOMMATES on t couch, watching a CRICKET GAME on TV. The third ROOMMATE irons his shirts on the table. They might be a bunch of guys watching the Super Bowl, bu instead of baseball caps they wear the Sikh at-home headcover, a simple dew-rag knotted on top; (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: instead of nachos and beer they nurse glasses of strong s tea, snacking from a bowl of dried chickpeas. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: And the atmosphere is not so convivial: they are four men without women, and far from home. EXT. TEMPLE (GURDWARA) вЂ”- LATER вЂ” MORNING 27

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan enters the temple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He removes his shoes, inserting them in a cubbyhole. OTHE SIKH WORSHIPPERS are doing the same. He follows them into INT. PRAYER ROOM, GURDWARA вЂ”- CONTINUOUS - MORNING 29

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a long, carpeted room. MEN in turbans and WOMEN w scarves sit on the floor meditating, praying, or listenin the MUSICIANS SINGING verses from the Holy Book (Granth Sahib) which lies open on a low platform next to them. A WORSHIPPER sits before the Book, reading its Punjabi text ANOTHER flicks a horse-hair switch above him (traditional to ward off flies and dust). Darwan approaches the book with palms together (namaste), kneeling and bowing. The Worshipper rises and takes his turn with the switch, while Darwan sits before the Book and reads... We hear the sound of the music playing. We also see kids six or seven seated in an a spacious room taking a Tabla class with an Old Tabla Teacher. INT. COMMUNAL ROOM, GURDWARA - MINUTES LATER -вЂ” MORNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan shares tea, food and CHAT with other WORSHIPPERS (eating communally is traditional following prayers).

dialogues.speaker: I/E_ STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: Darwan is driving along a park in Queens. He glances at a KOREAN COUPLE posing for wedding pictures before a founta His CELL RINGS. He pulls over to take the call.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (into phone) Okay...I have no one at three... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He opens his assignment book, starts writing. DARWAN (cont'd) Manhattan?... While the person on the other end talks, he watches the Korean couple change poses, beaming for the camera. He snaps back to the phone call when he hears a name: DARWAN (cont'd) Wendy Shields? Oh, yes. EXT. WENDY'S HOUSE вЂ” DAY 32 Darwan waits at the front door, his ear to the intercom. blast of STATIC, then Wendy's voice:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (INTERCOM filter) Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Darwan Singh. For your driving lesson, please.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God... INTERCOM BUZZES him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan gazes around, noting the clutter and the dust. Wendy arrives at the foot of the stairs: pallid, wearing black sweats this time, her reading glasses atop her head tangled in her hair.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I completely forgot. Anyway I've changed my mind about lessons.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Why, if I may ask?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Look, I'll pay you for today. I'm really sorry. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Don't pay me. But I will ask a small favor from you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well...of course.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Come sit in the car. The driver's seat. So you get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Uh, I'm in the middle of work.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Let me do my job just a little. INT. STUDENT CAR вЂ”- A LITTLE LATER вЂ” DAY 34 ANGLE ON KEY IN CAR IGNITION - WENDY's hand turns it CLOCKWISE -- one click.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: First position turns on the electrical system. Now second position... Wendy turns the key further. The motor THRUMS to life. AN ON MIRRORS - REAR, LEFT SIDE, RIGHT SIDE. DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) Next, you have three mirrors. Rear view, left, and right --

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I really don't need to learn this. My husband drives.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I never learned to cook because I thought my mother would always be there to cook for me. She is gone, and I am here, so I make my own food.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (drily) Your point? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (smiles; shrugs) No point. So: check your three mirrors. Then turn your head to see the blind spot. ON WENDY - her hands are tight with tension on the wheel. Darwan coaches her from the passenger seat. DARWAN (cont'd) Put on your left signal. Wendy gropes for the signal post and turns on the wipers instead.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Damn. Where is it? He indicates the signal. She flicks it down.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Now turn the wheel all the way to the left. (she obeys) Now the gas pedal. The car moves forward a mere foot -- she brakes suddenly. DARWAN (cont'd) What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: We're moving.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: That's good.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I think I don't like this.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (twinkles ) Well, you have to go forward now because I haven't taught you how to back up. Check your mirrors again. Turn your head... As she turns her head, an AMBULANCE SCREAMS past. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Nothing will happen. I am always here with the other brake. Now. Press your foot -- WENDY'S FOOT JABS THE ACCELERATOR. THE CAR LEAPS forward. DARWAN'S FOOT PRESSES HIS SAFETY BRAKE, STOPPING the car. DARWAN (cont'd) Press the pedal gradually. Down, and release. THE CAR JERKS further into the lane. DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) Straighten the wheel. THE TIRES swivel straight. DARWAN (cont'd) Press the pedal. Gradually... WENDY'S FOOT presses gradually down...on the brake. DARWAN (cont'd) The pedal, not the brake. THE CAR creeps forward. OVERHEAD SHOT - Slowly the car joins traffic.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (whimpers ) Where am I going?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: For now, it's simple: just go straight.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 35
dialogues.text: EXT. STREET - RICHMOND HILL - A LITTLE LATER вЂ”- NIGHT 3 Darwan walks with Preet, carrying groceries. Preet's CELL PHONE CHIRPS. Stopping, Preet checks his messages. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: Mom sent another photo. Darwan looks over Preet's shoulder at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: CELL SCREEN
dialogues.text: about 40, gazing stiffly at the camera as if for a passpo picture.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: She looks sour. She would complain a lot.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: Every time you find something wrong. How many more years until there's no one left and you're still alone? In your head, I think you're still in prison, Uncle D.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (roughly) Be quiet! Never speak to me like that again! Cowed, Preet shuts up. DARWAN (cont'd) You were just a skinny scared boy when I took you in. I promised your mother to help you and now you give me cheek, and disrespect. They walk for a beat in silence. Cooling off, Darwan mana a smile. DARWAN (cont'd) You were stinky, too. Smeared all over with garlic paste.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: (grins) They told me it would keep the rattlesnakes away in the desert.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: It's a wonder the border guards didn't smell you coming.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: But it worked!  37 8/21/13 23.

dialogues.speaker: I/E STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: With Darwan beside her, Wendy guides the car slowly up Broadway, where TRAFFIC is convoluted and aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Teach yourself to see everything. Your eyes should go from sidewalk to sidewalk, and one block ahead.

dialogues.speaker: TRAFFIC LIGHTS, CONSTRUCTION BARRIERS...
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) You see the markings on the road, the lights, you read the signs...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's too many to read.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It comes with time. POV - PASSING PEOPLE: A WOMAN WITH STROLLER steps off the curb; a DELIVERY MAN opens his van door; a SKATEBOARDER curves across the lane; KIDS around an MISTER SOFTEE TRUC DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) Be aware of living as well as non- living things. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) When you see a person ahead, try to guess what they'll do next...

dialogues.speaker: FRONT
dialogues.text: the car. Wendy YELPS, pumping the brake. DARWAN (cont'd) .--and smoothly adjust so you can stay out of their way. The driver's biggest problem is Everyone Else. You can't always trust people to behave properly.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (mutters ) Ain't that the truth. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: PAN TOWARD WENDY'S EYES, dutifully sweeping the street ah up, down, side to side... WENDY'S POV - PANNING TOWARD HAPPY COUPLES eating at side cafes, young couple kissing on the curb. A male gay coupl holding hands and an old couple arguing. SAFETY BRAKE - DARWAN'S FOOT comes down hard.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: That's a red light. Wendy snaps to attention, looks up: sure enough, she almo went through a RED LIGHT. She jokes to cover up her embarrassment.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Isn't it strange, that red has come to mean "stop" and "danger"? It strikes me that stopping is when you're safe, whereas going is dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Don't talk, Wendy. When you talk, you don't see. He points her eyes up. The LIGHT IS GREEN. Cars behind HO Wendy drives on, trying to stay focused. DARWAN (cont'd) Get in the left lane. Slow...Signal. WENDY gropes, finds the signal this time. DARWAN (cont'd) Read the signs...See everything...

dialogues.speaker: STREET AHEAD, PANNING FROM SIDE TO SIDE
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) Stop. Watch the light. WENDY'S POV - ON THE RED TRAFFIC LIGHT, then PANNING DOWN

dialogues.speaker: SEE
dialogues.text: TED (FANTASY) crossing the intersection ahead with his ar around a YOUNG WOMAN.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Ted...! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ted and the Young Woman pass from sight. Then Wendy turns head and... TED IS THERE BESIDE HER WINDOW, gazing at her impassively WENDY (cont'd) Don't you love me anymore? He shakes his head: no. WENDY (cont'd) But why? How did I fail you? What should I have done? When he opens his mouth to speak, the voice is Indian- accented.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (DARWAN'S VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pay attention!

dialogues.speaker: SMASHCUT TO
dialogues.text: Ted is gone, Darwan is beside her.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: The light. He's pointing up to the GREEN LIGHT. Rattled, she tromps on the pedal and the CAR LEAPS FORWAR DARWAN BRAKES on his side. The car avoids hitting a JAYWA with his iPod on loud.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God! She drops her hands to her lap helplessly with a GROAN of frustration; lowers her head.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Why didn't you see him? (beat) Were you wandering?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (looks up) I'm never going to be good at this.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Every time it will get easier. Now, drive on. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (in a child's voice) I can't.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Take the wheel. Press the pedal. She puts her hands on the wheel, then shakes her head no.

dialogues.speaker: THE VIEW THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD GOES BLURRY
dialogues.text: WATERY...Is it raining? No, it's: WENDY'S EYES FILLING UP WITH TEARS.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Can you drive me home?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (firm) No. You will do it, and I will help. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” DAY 38 Darwan and his nephew Preet huddle around his cell phone. Darwan is talking to his sister RASBIR (Preet's mother, m 40's) on FaceTime: she is seen in closeup on the phone's screen.

dialogues.speaker: RASBIR
dialogues.text: She's not young but she can still have one or two children.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Why hasn't she been married?

dialogues.speaker: RASBIR
dialogues.text: She was engaged once but the police shot her fiance, just like they did to our Sameer. Then her father was ill for a long time and needed her at home. Now he's dead and she has nowhere to go.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: (to Darwan) She's perfect!

dialogues.speaker: RASBIR
dialogues.text: She's the best one for you, Darwan. And very nice-looking. Did you like the photo? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Yes, but can I talk to her and see her like we're doing?

dialogues.speaker: RASBIR
dialogues.text: She won't come to the phone. She thinks you'll see she's too old. She says, "He won't like me."

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: He won't, Mommy!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I'll think about it. Rasbir, please...take the phone to the window. Show me the street, the sun, the sky, everything.

dialogues.speaker: RASBIR
dialogues.text: (shakes her head sadly) Bahpe [brother], it's night time here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: 27-27B.
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: RASBIR (cont'd) EXT. HIGH LINE FICKR POOL вЂ” DAY 38B Wendy and her sister DEBBIE pick up their SHWARMA lunch f a FOOD TRUCK.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Well hallelujah, sis, itвЂ™s about time you learned to drive.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m just doing it for Tasha, not because I need to. As they move to a pair of wooden chaises to sit and eat: WENDY (CONTвЂ™D) (contвЂ™d) But you have to drive, Debbie, you're in the suburbs. Here I have the subway, buses, taxis... (they sit) I also used to have a husband who drove.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (shakes her head) Ted. Such a creep - but you know? I can believe it. On my street alone we've had three divorces caused by philandering.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (starts eating) Oh well, Greenwich.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (inspecting the shwarma) What I don't understand is: how can they cheat on their wives and still live with themselves? I mean, it's like pissing in the pool. Maybe nobody saw you do it, but you know the yellow's in the water. And you have to swim around in it, pretending it's clean. Debbie manages to give Wendy the giggles.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: And how do they find all these sluts? Is there a vending machine? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I call them Play-Doh Bunnies. The guys can mold them into whatever they want. Teach them tricks. Like waking them up every morning with a blowjob.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (sad again) Maybe that's all Ted ever really wanted.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (tries a bite of the shwarma ) Honestly, it's nirvana for them.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (mouth full) Then why don't we do it?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: It's too much work. Why do you think they call it a job? The two break up, laughing harder and harder, trying to k their food from flying out of their mouths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy meets with her divorce ATTORNEY at a table in an em conference room. He raises

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: He wants "support"?!

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Or a twenty-five percent share of your income. He claims he supported you while you pursued your career. I know, I know -- a hand to forestall her rage; it doesn't work. She POUNDS the table with her fist.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: This is a man who was jealous of my career! Who criticized everything I did, to undermine me! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Wendy, it's normal. Each side asks for the outrageous, and they come together in the middle. Don't take it personally. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don't take it - ha! Ha ha ha ha! Just give him everything! If he agrees to be castrated. He waits for her to finish venting. His CELL PHONE VIBRAT on the table. He glances at the ID, then checks his notes

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: He'll let you stay in the house if you buy him out.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can't possibly afford that.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Or split fifty-fifty if you sell.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I have to move out?! I am that house. It's like asking me to move out of me.

dialogues.speaker: ATTORNEY
dialogues.text: Maybe it's too big now?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can't believe this. It's where we raised Tasha, where we were happy....

Her voice trails off. She realizes the word "happy" is no moot. Obsolete. WENDY (cont'd) Okay. It's where we were idiots, and squandered our marriage, and never made love when we should have and never fought when we should have, and we read and read and read and went totally fucking blind - and I want my house! I want to stay where I am!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Returning to his apartment, Darwan sees an American MAN leaning against a black CAR parked in front. Waiting. Something about him makes Darwan tense up instinctively.  4l 8/21/13 31. INT. OUTSIDE DARWAN'S APARTMENT - SECONDS LATER вЂ”- MAGI Pausing outside his door, Darwan hears MEN'S VOICES withi speaking English. TIGHT ON DARWAN - His face is suddenly bathed in sweat, h breathing ragged. XCU - HIS HAND goes slowly to the door knob. Before he ca turn it: THE DOOR BANGS OPEN. Two of Darwan's Sikh Roommates emerg escorted roughly by two official-looking men (IMMIGRATION AGENTS). His roommates look at Darwan with helpless dread they are rushed past. A third AGENT brings up the rear, stopping short when he Darwan.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (flashes badge to Darwan) I.N.S. Who're you?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I am Darwan Singh. American citizen.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Let's see your papers. With unsteady hands, Darwan removes his driver's license his wallet. The Agent examines it. AGENT (cont'd) How come they let you in, Darwan?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Political asylum.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (checks the year) 2000...you got in just under the wire. The Agent brusquely hands back the license and exits. Left alone, Darwan rushes into the living room. His roommates' half-finished tea stands on the table. An INDI SOAP OPERA still plays on the TV. The closets stand open, their contents strewn on the floor, the sofa upended, indicating a forcible search of the premises. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (to himself; frantic) Preet... There's a faint NOISE on the other side of a wall. DARWAN (cont'd) Preet! INT. BATHROOM вЂ”- BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” CONTINUOUS - DA As Darwan rushes in, the cabinet door under the sink THRO OPEN. Preet is inside, extricating himself from the vanit where he hid by contorting himself into an impossibly tig ball. He spills onto the bath mat, one foot still stuck i the plumbing. Darwan helps him up.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: (shaken) I thought they got me this time.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: They took Teji and Raam. Thank God you're safe.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: Only 'til next time. INT. BEDROOM вЂ” BASEMENT APARTMENT - A LITTLE LATER вЂ” The bedroom's a mess, too, from the agents' search: cloth all over the floor and the bed upended. Preet stuffs his belongings into a duffel while Darwan pleads with him.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I'll find us another place -

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: I'm going to live with my girlfriend in Chinatown.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (taken aback) You have a girlfriend?

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: They won't look for me if I'm with her. She's Jewish. (off Darwan's shock) Uncle D, you knew I would go sometime. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: This is a very poor decision. My sister will blame me.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: I tell her, Mom, this is America. I can do what I want. As long as they don't ask for my papers. INT. LIVING ROOM вЂ” BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ”- LATER вЂ” MA Darwan is left alone in the dishevelled apartment. He mak no move to clean up. As night falls, he remains leaning against the wall, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan sits in prayer. His attention is drawn to: AN OLDER SIKH MAN praying with his WIFE alongside him. Th lips move together. EXT. WENDY'S HOUSE вЂ” DAY 46 Darwan waits in the student car in his customary spot, pa at the hydrant in front of Wendy's house. A lovesick INDI BALLAD plays on his radio. He hardly hears it, still deep thought. Wendy bursts from the house, her hair chaotic, glowering anger over her divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The student car creeps through Harlem to Washington Heigh Wendy's attention is everywhere but the road.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Point your eyes at the middle of the lane. The same as a gun. Your peripheral vision sees all the rest. ANGLE - PASSING A PAIR OF STREET TOUGHS. They spot Darwan with his turban.

dialogues.speaker: TOUGH KID
dialogues.text: (yells) Osama! Thought we killed you! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The Kid HIT the hood of the car as it stops at the crossw

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (YELLS out window) Shut up, asshole! (to Darwan) Does that happen to you a lot?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Every day. People try to push your buttons. You don't engage with them. Especially when you drive. She comes to a stop at the intersection. DARWAN (cont'd) You are on top of the crosswalk. Next time stop where you can see the lines. ON WENDY - grits her teeth. The constant stream of critic even delivered in Darwan's neutral tone, is getting to he Traffic moves again. Suddenly a SPORTS CAR ZOOMS past, an abruptly in front of her, inches from the bumper, cutting off. Wendy POUNDS THE HORN.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: God damn it!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Don't lean on the horn. It's not a boat. Just a short tap.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Why do men have to do that? Wag their balls in your face.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (controls his shock) I think it is time to discuss road rage. You must learn to be calm and relaxed, not only to drive but in your life as well.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: And how do you manage that?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Prayer helps me. I pray every day. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I unfriended God a long time ago... Guess you've got lots of friends up there. All those gods of yours.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I am not Hindu. I am a Sikh. We have only one God, like yours.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Then I'm mad at your God, too. He says nothing. She turns her head to glance at him. He' impassive, as if he didn't hear her, focusing only on the road. WENDY (cont'd) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Eyes forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car passes through the narrow tree-lined streets of CASTLE VILLAGE. TUDOR HOUSES. A RABBI crosses the street; ELDERLIES walk their DOGS, KIDS in Catholic uniforms retu from school.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Be careful to see every person before you. They may not have the right of way but you are the one driving a deadly weapon... He looks over. Wendy has a glazed look he has come to kno well. She doesn't notice she's rolling right through a ST SIGN. DARWAN'S HAND WRENCHES THE WHEEL FROM HER. THE CAR pulls over to the curb. DARWAN (cont'd) Where were you just now? You don't seem to notice anything. Observation, Wendy, observation. This is your weakness.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (snaps ) Are you channeling my husband? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Tell me why you want to drive.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: To go somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: And how do you want to get there?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (off-guard) "How"?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You want to arrive in one piece? Or two pieces? Or three?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (looks away; haughtily) Don't patronize me.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Look at me. The urgency in his voice makes her turn back to him. She surprised to see the depth of compassion in his eyes, although she has spent the lesson baiting him. DARWAN (cont'd) It doesn't matter what is going on in your life out there, you must shut it out. When you are here, when you are at the wheel of a car, this is all there is. Your life: right now. So take care of it,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: please. FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy opens the door for a CLEANING CREW.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. BASEMENT APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Darwan unlocks the door to basement apartment. LATER - Working shirtless, runs a dry vacuum over the floor...cuts and lays carpet.... He hangs a mirror...a shower curtain... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Preet helps him haul a king-size mattress through the door....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cleaners attack the house. Wendy tosses clutter into garbage bags... KNOCK-KNOCK 0O.S.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. BASEMENT APARTMENT
dialogues.text: Darwan opens the door, and his FRIENDS lug in boxes of electronic equipment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy lets the cleaners out. She turns: everything is nea and spotless. INT. WENDY'S BEDROOM - LATER вЂ” DAY 54 Standing before the mirror, Wendy checks her dress. It lo new. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” LATER вЂ” DAY 55

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's done. A big FLAT-SCREEN TV is perched on a cabinet a with a DVD PLAYER, SPEAKERS and SUB-WOOFER. Everyone's ve excited. Darwan plays with four remotes, trying to turn t TV on. At last, the image ignites on the screen. DING-DONG 0O.S. The doorbell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy opens the door. It's Ted. Apparently she's been expecting him.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Hi. He's braced for a fight, but instead she smiles cheerily.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Come on in. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He steps in, registering surprise at her makeover.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You look fine.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Therefore I am. INT. LIVING ROOM, WENDY'S HOUSE - LATER вЂ”- DAY 57 Ted's reaching down his books from the bookcase, filling cartons. Wendy is curled up on the couch, watching.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Do you think books miss their owners? They pine, they waste away?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Or they get a new haircut and hit the singles scene.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So many choices, when you're single. He's silent, won't touch that, his back to her as he reac more books down. WENDY (cont'd) Should I look for a two or three- bedroom apartment? High-rise or low- rise?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: We're looking for a place in Nyack. She shifts uncomfortably, her heart sinking.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That's a long commute.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I enjoy the drive. I love a big bridge over a big river. Human genius vaulting over the primeval ooze.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Really. (re: books) You're leaving me "The Joy of Sex"? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: It's yours. I gave it to you for Valentine's.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't remember reading it.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: You put it in a drawer.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, toss it here. (he does) Let's see if there's anything we didn't cover. (checks table of contents) Missionary, check. Standing, check. Rear entry, check. Wait. Did we do "The Viennese Oyster"? Without responding, he hefts a carton and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ted finishes loading his double-parked car with cartons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Ted re-enters, Wendy has put a box full of photograp on the coffee table.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Guess that's it.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Here're some photos I found, you might want.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: I'm double-parked. Wendy's smiling at a photo she's picked from the pile.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: This one's from Moose River. Lured over, he sits beside her on the couch as she hands the photo. He grins at the image.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Natasha was what, six? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: She was eight, the cabin was six. Degrees below zero.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First and last camping trip. (re: next photo) Halloween?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (swats him playfully) No! Shoulder pads were in then. Ted looks at a few more pictures. Wendy watches him carefully. Sighing, he puts them down, suddenly deflated.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: This is hard.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yes. Beat. WENDY (cont'd) I'm finding I can do hard things. I'm learning to drive, you know.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: That's a scary thought, Miss McGoo.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can drive, I can keep a clean house, I can doll myself up, I can bake a cherry pie... She slides to her knees in front of him. WENDY (cont'd) I can give you what you need. He's frozen, unsure this is really happening, as she reac to undo his belt buckle. WENDY (cont'd) I can make you love me again.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Wendy -- this just isn't you. She smiles seductively, parting his fly. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Why not me?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (laughs nervously) Since when did you become lapdancer? She reaches inside his pants and bends her head...He pull her hands away from his open fly. TED (cont'd) Sweetheart, don't...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: God! To hear you call me that again is wonderful. She goes for his mouth, bringing her lips to his -- O.S. BEEP-BEEP-BEEP: a truck backing up on the street outside; then the ROAR OF HEAVY MACHINERY. Ted bounds off couch.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: Holy shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The OPERATOR of a city TOW TRUCK is just putting the big in Ted's front bumper. Ted runs into the street, YELLING in protest. WENDY IN THE DOORWAY watches, demoralized...then shuts th door.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. No. She is not this kind of woman. 61 INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ”- QUEENS вЂ” DAY 61

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PREET and his Uncle are sitting in the apartment looking through a lingerie catalog at women dressed in scanty panties, saucy push-up bras, peekaboo satin nighties...

dialogues.speaker: PREET, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How do you know? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: She will be modest, I think. This would shock her.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: Trust me! All women, they want these things.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: (follows, teasing) And what about you, Uncle D? Don't you want it?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I don't want her to get the idea that this is how I think of her. It's disrespectful.

dialogues.speaker: PREET
dialogues.text: (exasperated GROAN) It's bad enough you don't understand women. But you don't even understand yourself.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I'll wait for her birthday. EXT. WENDY'S STREET -вЂ” DAY 62 ANGLE ON TIRES of student car ROLLING BACKWARD slowly.... They swivel sharply, still backing up...then with a JOLT, THEY MOUNT THE CURB.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh shit, oh shit...!

dialogues.speaker: I/E. STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: Wendy leans her head against the wheel in frustration. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I'm so lost. Darwan taps her on the back gently. She turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy, how do you know if you've put in enough salt and pepper when you are making a beef stew?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You taste it?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Right. So what do you do if you've lost track of the way the car is pointing when you parallel-park?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You taste it?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You just let the car move back a tiny bit and see which way it goes -- you taste the direction.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: And then you correct the seasoning?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Right. You adjust a little bit, and a little bit -- and now I've made myself hungry. I will go home and make myself a curry. She smiles wanly, preoccupied. DARWAN (cont'd) You look very nice today. She looks at him as if seeing a man for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: He writes her receipt on the hood of the car while she wr a check. As they make the exchange, he looks as if he wan to say something but has lost his courage. Then he blurts (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy...what does a woman like for a gift?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't know, candy, flowers... Speaking for myself, a book of poetry.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (brightens ) Ah!...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: My husband gave me that on our first date and every anniversary. He'd mark a certain love poem and ask me to read it while he lay his head in my lap. (wistfully) It was the perfect gift.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Yes, a fine idea.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (rips check out of book) What about you? What present do you like?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS; accepts it) A check, of course. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT -вЂ” NIGHT 64 Darwan carefully wraps a small book in gift paper.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: He puts the final touches on his new home, hanging a pict of the Sikhs' Golden Temple; another of the First Guru, father of Sikhism. PAN TOWARD THE LAST PICTURE he's hanging: of his parents, FATHER posed stiffly, proud in his white turban; HIS MOTH languidly leaning her head on her hand and smiling warmly INT. LIVING ROOM вЂ” WENDY'S HOUSE - NIGHT 65

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON MOROCCAN TABLE LAMP with ornate stained glass sh (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (into phone) How can you claim the Moroccan lamp as a pre-marital asset?! WIDEN ANGLE TO INCLUDE - WENDY pacing with the cordless phone, and brandishing a page from a legal document. WENDY (cont'd) (into phone) We bought it together, Ted! (tears page in half) Hear that? I'm tearing this in half. Now you can shove it up both your ass and your lawyer's!

dialogues.speaker: I/E STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: It's a sweltering day: muggy, yellowish sky. Even with th windows rolled down, Darwan and Wendy are drenched in swe She drives east along Central Park South, passing SKATEBOARDERS with their shirts off; JOGGERS pouring Evia over their heads; mobs of CHILDREN around the ICE CREAM SELLER. HORSES with drooping heads hauling carriages of TOURISTS. A PEDI-CAB DRIVER pedals stoically in the heat alongside her.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Why don't you have air-conditioning in this heap?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: The school buys the cheapest cars. I will take you someplace cooler. He smiles mysteriously. EXT. 59TH STREET вЂ”- MINUTES LATER вЂ” DAY 67 Wendy waits in heavy traffic at a stoplight. Looking ahea she realizes that the street ascends straight into...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God! It's a bridge!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Today you are going over a bridge. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The LIGHT CHANGES. But Wendy is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can't!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Just keep going. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The car behind her BLASTS its horn angrily.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I'm afraid of heights!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: We'll take it slowly. Now go straight.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Please don't make me do it. The HONKING GROWS as more cars join in.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy, you must move. The car creeps forward. The LIGHT CHANGES before she has reached the opposite side of the intersection. Now the CR TRAFFIC APPROACHES and she's "blocking the box." More HONKING. Wendy and Darwan shout above the noise:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Why are you forcing me to do this?!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Because I know what you can do better than you! His calm obstinacy infuriates her, but there's no choice: must drive ahead, and that means mounting the bridge. Her fingers tighten on the wheel. GREEN LIGHT. She drives forward, slow as a tortoise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The student car creeps over the bridge, the East River stretched out below.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Don't look down. Focus on the center of the lane, and it's just another road. Except it's in the sky. Think of yourself as a bird. You are floating on the wind. Feel how happy it is, how easy --

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Darwan, this is terrifying!! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Fear is a good thing. If you are afraid, then you will pay more attention. No more tuning out, Wendy.

dialogues.speaker: I/E_ STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: They've arrived in Queens. Wendy is a wreck.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Congratulations. You can let go the death grip now.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God, I never want to do that again!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: But you have to drive back.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: No, you will drive us back.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: No way. I'm happy here in Queens. EXT. QUEENS - SEQUENCE OF SHOTS вЂ” DAY 70

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONTAGE OF QUEENS NEIGHBORHOODS, as Wendy drives through; Darwan and Wendy converse O.S.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Queens is part of New York, too. PASSING an Asian district, where throngs of SHOPPERS stro under signs in Chinese, Thai, Singaporean, Malaysian; pas karaoke bars, Chinese herb shops... DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) We don't have skyscrapers and Times Square and Trump palaces. We only have...more people. PASSING the "African Poetry Theater," PEOPLE on the stree wear dashikis and doo-rags... DARWAN (0.S.) (cont'd) Many different people. Families. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have your family here, too?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just my nephew, my sister's son. She lives in Punjab. PASSING under the arcade of the elevated subway line, we LATINOS -- Filipino, Ecuadorian, Peruvian -- on the stree open produce markets with Spanish signs...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Your parents? PASSING A PARK where a group of East INDIANS have gathere a small stream, scattering a deceased person's ashes.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: They're dead. OUT THE WINDOW - TAIWANESE KIDS flying MODEL PLANES in th park. PAN UP TO SEE A JUMBO JET ROAR low above the treetops, he for JFK Airport...

dialogues.speaker: I/E_ STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: Wendy swerves the car onto a small street of huddled cottages: a working-class neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (frowns ) I didn't tell you to turn.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (grins) I'm showing you my Queens. This is where I grew up.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You're from Queens?! After a double-take, he bursts out LAUGHING. DARWAN (cont'd) You played a good joke on me. WENDY'S POV - PASSING an old heap at the curb. In the driver's seat is a MAN in a Mets' cap, smoking. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Dad used to sit in his car, just like that, listening to the ball game on the radio, whenever my mother kicked him out of the house. Which was pretty often. He took off one day and we never saw him again. My sister and I were left alone to raise our mother. Wendy picks up some speed as she continues talking. WENDY (cont'd) -.-I had scoliosis so I had to spend a year in a cast in bed. That's when I got into books. They were my ride. Darwan takes his eyes off the road to watch her in profil WENDY (cont'd) "Smarty Wendypants" he called me. He would've been proud to see me go to Barnard. SEAGULLS are in the air. The car is headed for the beache Far Rockaway. MANHATTAN is seen across the water, with it clutter of skyscrapers, through heat haze... WENDY (cont'd) I can't believe you got me here. I'm allergic to Queens.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: There will be a reward.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT STUDENT CAR- BOARDWALK, FAR ROCKAWAY
dialogues.text: Wendy parks in the lot near the boardwalk, and the long s of beach where the whole MELTING POT of Queens comes to l in the sand and play in the waves. Wendy relinquishes the wheel with a GROAN.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (jumping out of the car) Wait here. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ON WENDY - watching him stride onto the boardwalk. She tu the RADIO on, tuning it until she gets a BASEBALL GAME. S smiles to herself, then looks up. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WENDY'S POV THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD (FANTASY) - A man in a Mets' cap stands in front of the bumper, smiling back at It's WENDY'S FATHER, as she imagines him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi, Dad. Well, here I am. Sitting in your seat, and the Mets are playing Arizona.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Good for you, Wendypants . About time you took the wheel. WE PAN TO THE PASSENGER SEAT, where her father has reappeared, sitting beside her.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY'S FATHER
dialogues.text: (pats the dashboard) A car's the greatest thing in the history of human invention. Forget your house, you could move in here. Sleep in the back. Heat up a TV dinner in the engine. Here's your shower. He switches on the WIPER FLUID, spraying the front window She GIGGLES. WENDY'S FATHER (cont'd) Pee in the gas tank. And when the spirit moves, you just drive away. ON WENDY - not laughing anymore.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Like you drove away, Dad? And never came back. A KNOCK ON THE DRIVER'S WINDOW makes her turn her head. Darwan is there, holding two ice cream bars.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Here is your reward. EXT. BEACH - LATER вЂ” DAY 74 TRACK WITH WENDY AND DARWAN eating ICE CREAM BARS as they stroll away from the SUNBATHERS.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You have a masters, really? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I was a university professor, like my father.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Then why do you teach driving?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: For a better job I would have to take off my turban, shave my beard. People think I look dangerous. But this is how I know who I am. And here it is too easy to forget.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Don't you go back for visits?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I can never go home to India. It's part of political asylum. I could not see my father before he died last year.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I didn't get a chance to say goodbye to my dad either.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I missed my mother's funeral, too, but that was when I was in prison there.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (taken aback) Why?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: For nothing. For being a Sikh. The police had already killed my brother. They said he was a terrorist, and they had to shoot him because he ambushed them, but it was a lie. Then they punished the rest of the family. All of us were tortured, my father, my uncle, even my mother. They let my sister alone because she was too young. Back then there was no justice for Sikhs.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How long were you in prison? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: A long time. 8/21/13 51A. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His tone is carefully placid, but a shadow passes over hi face. He stares at the waves. Wendy can tell the subject closed. He returns to the present, as if switching something off. DARWAN (cont'd) But here is the ocean. Punjab is nowhere near water. The SKY HAS GONE DARK. RUMBLING O.S. A summer THUNDERSTOR gathering. Darwan glances at his watch, suddenly alarmed. DARWAN (cont'd) It's very late!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I have time. He turns to rush back to the car.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: We have to get you back to Manhattan. (to himself) Oh my God...  75 8/21/13 53.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. INTERSECTION
dialogues.text: Heavy traffic. The student car stops at a light at a big intersection. THUNDER GROWLS; LIGHTNING FLASHES. The SKY DARKER. PEDESTRIANS cross in front of her car. Among them is a MA A METS' CAP. He pulls his windbreaker hood over his head, obscuring his face.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (softly) Dad...?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Turn on your lights.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (looks around) Where? Where? He snatches her hand and puts it on the light dial. He is being unusually impatient and brusque with her.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Dial to the next position. She returns her eyes quickly to the intersection. WENDY'S POV - The Man in the Met's cap is gone. WENDY turns her head. The Man APPEARS beside her open win His windbreaker hood is pulled down; his face is in shado

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Dad! He doesn't move. WENDY (cont'd) Just tell me one thing, please, Mom said it was an accident, but - did you do it on purpose? Did you want to die? To get away from us? From me? She's CRYING now. DARWAN'S VOICE CUTS THROUGH, incongruou

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You have the light! Go now! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Man) Did you ever love me? The Man pulls back his hood suddenly. LIGHTNING FLASHES, revealing HIS FACE IS CRUSHED, A BLOODIED MASS from impac with a windshield. WENDY SCREAMS! Simultaneously, a CRACK OF THUNDER! And -

dialogues.speaker: HER FOOT HITS THE BRAKE
dialogues.text: HER BRAKE LIGHTS FLASH -- too late. The CAR BEHIND BARREL into the rear of the student car: CRASH! Wendy and Darwan are thrown forward against their belts. THE REAR BUMPER of the student car crumples.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER CAR REAR-ENDS THE CAR BEHIND HER
dialogues.text: The force of the second collision forces the first car ev further into Wendy's rear. THE TRUNK CAVES, THE LID POPS OPEN. Even the "WINDSOR DRIVING SCHOOL" placard on the ro is knocked to one side. The skies open. SHEETS OF RAIN DELUGE the scene. 77 (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: I/E_ STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: Darwan is beside himself, yelling at her:

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Why did you stop? Wendy cowers in the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't know --

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Oh my dear God -- pull over!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (throws her hands up helplessly) I can't!
76 78 Darwan runs around to take the driver's seat while Wendy slides over. Traffic is backed up behind the crash and HONKING belligerently. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Darwan drives the wounded car over to the curb. The other vehicles follow suit. A DRIVER AND PASSENGER(BOTH DRIVER and PASSENGER) get out inspect their crunched hood, and bumper. Darwan jumps out of the student car without a word to Wen He approaches the other driver. The Driver is furious.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: I just got through paying for this car! DRIVER is enraged, spotting Darwan's beard and turban. DRIVER (cont'd) Fucking Arab asshole!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Please, it was my student --

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Go back to your fucking cave!

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: Stop! Driver punches his Darwan's turban off; KICKS the side of student car, leaving a dent. PASSENGER restrains DRIVER; Darwan, humiliated, scrambles to retrieve his turban from ground where it has unraveled. His long hair (which has n been cut, according to Sikh tradition) swings free, a ski rope uncoiling to the small of his back. He looks suddenl shockingly, naked without the turban. PASSENGER (cont'd) Stop! Can we just do the insurance cards and get the fuck outa here! INSIDE STUDENT CAR - Wendy sits stunned. The PASSENGER DOOR WRENCHES open. DARWAN reaches in, his hair hanging; he tosses the muddied turban in, YANKS open glove compartment, extracts his INSURANCE CARD AND REGISTRATION with trembling hands, and SLAMS the door shu again. A POLICE CAR arrives on the scene, its ROOF LIGHTS are twirling. A COP gets out and approaches the huddle of MEN. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN'S POV - THE COP'S BADGE moving closer... ON DARWAN - his eyes instinctively fill with fear; he bec short of breath.

dialogues.speaker: MINUTES LATER
dialogues.text: His report pad out, the cop interviews the Drivers.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: What happened first?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (indicates Darwan) He stopped for no reason.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: It was a student driver, sir... The Cop notes Darwan's turban and his unease.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Where you from?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Richmond Hill.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Yeah, but where're you from?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: India.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: You got papers?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (produces ID) I am an American citizen. Cop scrutinizes Darwan's ID and license.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Stay here. (to Driver and Passenger) Get in your car and have your license and registrations ready. The Cop takes Darwan's papers back to the police car. BACK IN THE CAR - Wendy senses Darwan is in trouble. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: WENDY JUMPS OUT, intercepts the Cop.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Officer, it was my fault. I was driving.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: Remain in the car, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (belligerent) I have two words for you: Racial. Profiling. (to Darwan) Are they harassing you?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Wendy, stay in the car.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: This is a no-fault accident, ma'am. I'm just filling out a report.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON DIGITAL CAR CLOCK - as the minutes shift. WENDY, in the passenger seat, keeps glancing back. WENDY'S POV - Darwan paces, talks on his cell phone, gesticulating. LATER - DRIVER and his Passenger leave in their car. Darwan waits, seated on the curb, his head bowed. The Cop leans into his police car, conferring with his PARTNER inside. Darwan looks on anxiously. WENDY'S EYES fall to the rear seat. There's a hand-letter cardboard SIGN reading "JASLEEN KAUR", a bouquet of FLOWE wrapped in cellophane, and a gift-wrapped BOOK. She has a sinking feeling he bought them for her. The Cop returns, handing back Darwan's papers and the accident report. Everything happens very fast: the sky opens; TORRENTIAL R POURS down in sheets;

dialogues.speaker: SECONDS LATER
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan gets in the student car, stuffs the papers in the glove compartment. But not before getting soaking wet fro

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Is everything okay? Not responding, he catches sight of the clock, and become even more agitated.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Put on your seat belt.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (repeats) Is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: What is "okay"?! I have a car bashed up to hell and my boss angry at me! STUDENT CAR -вЂ” CONTINUOUS - NIGHT 79

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car is still parked as DARWAN collects himself from t recent activities. The rain continues.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I'll pay to have it fixed.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You pay nothing. The school has insurance. But the five-hundred dollar deductible, who pays that? I do! Do you know how much I work for five hundred dollars?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can give you that.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I cannot take your money. That is not how I am. What were you doing? All you have to do is drive straight through an intersection, everything is clear -- and you stop! (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: My mind went somewhere, just for a second.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Bad things happen in just one second! You can lose everything! And you don't get another try!

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (defensive) I was thinking. I'm an intellectual.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You can think about anything you want when you write, but when you drive you think only about driving! (brusquely) I don't have time to take you home now.
