I have to pick up somebody at the airport, and I am very late. He quickly pulls the car away from the curb and races thr the AMBER LIGHT, joining the traffic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parked the parking lot, Darwan yanks down the rear view mirror to fix his turban, stuffing his hair haphazardly inside and frantically winding the cloth around his head. Wendy looks on mutely as he grabs the sign, flowers, and from the back seat of the student car. He jumps out, leav Wendy inside the car.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (curt) Stay here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An Air India flight has arrived; the last of the TRAVELLE are leaving: women in vivid saris and men in Nehru suits. Darwan holds his sign aloft, searching the travellers' fa in vain. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: His turban is askew, and the end of the soggy cloth has c loose, hanging over his eyes so he has to swat it away. The pavement empties. Then DARWAN spots a small, plump 30 something INDIAN WOMAN about 50 feet away, sitting alone her LUGGAGE; on her lap is a clear plastic garment bag wi long ornate red gown inside. He holds up his sign hopefully, but she makes no sign of recognition. As he approaches her, she glances up, bleary from the fli

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Jasleen?

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: Darwan? She seems a bit stunned. He realizes he could not look wo dishevelled and drenched, his shirt sticking to his skin, turban askew and unravelling.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Hello. Did you not see my sign? (she looks confused) Never mind. Here is for you. He hands her the flowers and the wrapped gift. DARWAN (cont'd) Please, open it. She unwraps the paper. She stares blankly at the book ins DARWAN (cont'd) These are beautiful poems for you to read. William Wordsworth!

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: (ill at ease) Thank you, mister.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mister! We will speak only English now, for practise. You will learn fast. She gives him a box of Indian candy from her tote. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) Thank you. I have not tasted these in twelve years! He waits for her to say more, but she's like a deer in th headlights. DARWAN (cont'd) Now I will show you New York! He offers to take her garment bag, but she won't release He picks up her three suitcases, staggering to the car. S follows, arms full of flowers, garment bag, and poetry bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they approach his car, he's acutely aware of what she sees: the dented door, the smashed rear, the placard aske and an attractive middle-aged Caucasian woman waiting bes the vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (flustered) It's a little accident we had. That's my student, Wendy. Wendy, this is Jasleen.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hi. Jasleen looks at her suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: Hello, miss.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (tactfully) I'll get in the back. Wendy is hunkered in the rear. Darwan piles Jasleen's lug to the ceiling next to her.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (to Wendy; petulant) I cannot put these in the trunk because it is filled with rain. His movements are nervous; he is now so upset he seems unhinged. He goes to take the garment bag from Jasleen, w first clings to it. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: I want - careful!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: No problem, it will be safe. Darwan hands the bag to Wendy in the rear seat as climbs into the passenger seat. DARWAN (cont'd) (to Wendy) Hang this on the hook. As Wendy hangs the bag on the hook over her door, turns her head to watch, frowning.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: My dress...

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (climbs into driver seat) It's her wedding dress.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Jasleen) Oh, you're getting married? Jasleen doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Speak slowly so she understands.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (to Jasleen) You get married?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Yes. Tomorrow. We are very happy. Wendy is stupefied.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You two? As he pulls the car away from the curb:

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (to Wendy; hotly) Yes! Can you imagine how embarrassing this is? (voice reaches a SHOUT) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 Jasleen Jasleen (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) I look like a drowned dog, I have to pick her up in a pile of junk -- this is not how our first meeting was to be!! He is speaking so fast, Jasleen can't understand; she can only cringe against her door, witnessing his anger with n idea of the cause. The car heads out of the parking lot. DARWAN (cont'd) (to Jasleen) We must take Wendy home first. (gestures out window) Look, here is America! Jasleen sees nothing outside but bleak concrete and steri streetlights through a scrim of humid exhaust.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Excuse me, you've never met her?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: She's from a village near where I grew up. My sister picked her out for me.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (sitting back) If my sister picked me a husband, he'd be some dickless Republican banker.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Yes, you are better off! (mutters ) That's why you're alone and crazy.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Listen, just drop me at the subway. He SWERVES around ANOTHER CAR, thrusting the women agains their doors, while he shakes his finger back at Wendy:

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: No! You are my guest! You don't understand, this is how we are, we do everything for our guest before we think of ourselves! This is the Sikh way! (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) (to Jasleen) So, am I the way you pictured me? WIDE EXTERIOR ANGLE - The maimed student car drives out o frame, its trunk lid bouncing up and down.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: INT. TEMPLE (GURDWARA) -вЂ” NEXT DAY DARWAN and JASLEEN stand before the GIANI, or priest, and HOLY BOOK. Members of the WEDDING PARTY, all Darwan's friends, are dressed in a riot of colors: flame, fuschia, saffron, emerald; the men in turbans and long shirts of rainbow hues. Jasleen, heavily made up, with henna'd hands, wears her scarlet wedding dress and gold bangles; Darwan wears a scarlet turban and ceremonial sword. Darwan holds one end of a saffron sash, Jasleen the other he leads her four times around the Holy Book. The Priest MUSICIANS SING the sacred couplets which accompany each t

dialogues.speaker: PRIEST
dialogues.text: (first round) "Thus the Lord imprints the duties of married life..." Preet grins, winks at him as he passes by. PRIEST (cont'd) (second round) "Thus the Lord leads you to your Divine Guide..." Jasleen follows three steps behind Darwan, staring at her feet so as not to trip. PRIEST (cont'd) (third round) "Thus God's love fills your mind..." (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She timidly lifts her eyes to the back of her groom, his square shoulders, his confident stride. PRIEST (cont'd) (fourth round) "Thus you find the fruit of your heart's desire in God's name." INT. TEMPLE (GURDWARA)- COMMUNAL SPACE вЂ” NIGHT The wedding GUESTS dance exuberantly, under colored LIGHT to the loud "BANGHARA" MUSIC from a BOOMBOX. DARWAN is dancing, too. JASLEEN looks on shyly from the sidelines. Her eyelids droop: she's very tired and she doesn't know anyone. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ”- LATER вЂ” NIGHT Jasleen waits in the bed. Darwan, his back to her, unwrap his turban....

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It's a always a trade-off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WOMAN'S VOICE CONTINUES: it's a BROKER showing Wendy around an empty sun-filled apartment.

dialogues.speaker: BROKER
dialogues.text: You want a lot of light, you have to sacrifice on space. Or you buy a bigger place, and sacrifice your light... Wendy wanders about without enthusiasm, not really listen INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” DAY Jasleen unpacks her cosmetics on Darwan's bureau. She hangs her scarves next to his ties. She arranges a FRAMED PHOTO OF HER PARENTS next to his.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Jasleen gazes up at the waning light in the street-level window, where she can see the FEET OF PASSERSBY going to fro. INT. LIVING ROOM вЂ” WENDY'S HOUSE - DAY 91

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy's taking books from the shelves to pack in open cartons. A tragic OPERA plays faintly on a PBS station. Wendy's mood is correspondingly stormy. WE FOLLOW HER FEET as she approaches a box, then LINGER O BOOK lying open on the floor. It's the YELLOW PAGES, open "DRIVING INSTRUCTION." A few ads are half-heartedly circl When her feet return to frame, she abruptly KICKS the boo aside. She carries the GLASS-SHADED MOROCCAN LAMP to a box fille with bubble wrap. She raises the lamp carefully, turns, a with all her force SMASHES it on the floor. She throws herself onto the couch, curling into a ball, h hands covering her head. Then she hears a FAINT NOISE 0O. something brushing against the front door. Retreating FOOTSTEPS on the stoop outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LOW ANGLE - A folded note rests on the floor, slid throug the mail slot on the door. WENDY'S HAND PICKS UP THE NOTE WENDY unfolds the letter and reads. Takes a deep, gratefu breath. EXT. WENDY'S HOUSE вЂ” DAY 93 Darwan waits in his usual place, parked at the fire hydra He's in a different student car. He checks his watch. Wendy comes out of her house at last. He jumps out and me her halfway, escorting her down the stoop, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You make me wait. Punishing me?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (coy) Maybe. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Well, I'm happy we will finish what we started. I will not let you fail your license, Wendy. Approaching the car:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How was the wedding? She can't help the hint of jealousy in her voice. He does notice.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: It's a very, very beautiful ceremony. It says when a man and a woman marry, they become one spirit. We think and feel the same, there's no difference between us.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: You don't mention love.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Of course. Love is the one road to God. God doesn't want anyone to be alone. She raises a sardonic eyebrow. He opens the driver's door her to get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to turn on the ignition key.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Seat belt first. As she pulls the seat belt across her chest:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So what's it like to wake up married to a complete stranger?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I think you don't approve of arranged marriage. Check your mirrors. (as she does so) I'll try to explain. We hold our families very close. They know you better than anyone else. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) They're more objective about who's the right person for you. She TURNS ON THE ENGINE, puts on her signal light. DARWAN (cont'd) If you're left to your own devices, there's more chance you'll pick the wrong one. You choose for your ego.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't know what I believed about marriage. (as she pulls out) Except that it would always be there. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” DAY 95 Jasleen irons Darwan's shirts; glances now and then at th curious images on TV, where a hefty WOMAN tearfully smack and punches a beefy GUY beside her on a Maury Povich-type show. The subtitle, which she can't read, is: "HER BOYFRI

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Lying on the couch, she watches "SESAME STREET," featurin the letter "P." A short animated sequence teaches the wor "Peligro" (danger). Jasleen mouths the word:

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: Peligro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cooks dinner, enjoying INDIAN RAP MUSIC on the stereo ANGLE ON BASEMENT WINDOW - DARWAN'S TAXI pulls up. DARWAN enters, between shifts. Without asking her, he tur the MUSIC OFF. He looks over her shoulder at the pot on t stove.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: More tomatoes make a nicer color.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: I not have. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (gently) Jasleen, I give you money. You can go out and buy tomatoes.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: I not know where.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Just walk down the street, there are so many stores. She lapses into silence. They are awkward with each other still: he's aloof and formal, she is reticent.

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: She serves dinner. He tastes her cooking. She waits for h approval. She sighs.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) A little too much ghee.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: I try no much.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: If you don't have conversations with people outside, how will you pick up English?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Then tell me what you learned today.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: (smiles with pride) Peligro.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Spanish, not English. At the basement window, Jasleen watches Darwan's feet approach his taxi at the curb. He gets in and drives off. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Curled on the bed, Jasleen surfs the TV channels. PAN TOW

dialogues.speaker: GAVEL...AMERICA'S NEXT TOP MODEL...HOUSEWIVES OF WHATEVER
dialogues.text: having a cat fight...HILLARY CLINTON...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Darwan returns from his taxi shift. Jasleen wakes when he crawls into bed next to her; he falls immediately asleep. She pulls the divider curtain closed on him and retreats the TV. "MY LITTLE PONY" is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy's sister DEBBIE (about 5 years younger) and her HUS are having cocktails with a male FRIEND at a table for fo Wendy arrives, breathless. Kissing her sister and brother law briskly:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Sorry I'm late. The Male Friend stands to pull out Wendy's chair for her.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: (to Man) My sister is never on time.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE'S HUSBAND
dialogues.text: Wendy, this is Peter Hines. A squash buddy of mine. He annihilates me once a week. PETER (50-60) has a raffish smile; handsome; impeccable presentation: all buffed and bespoke.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Hello. She glares at her sister. She was not expecting the extra male.

dialogues.speaker: A LITTLE LATER
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter is studying the wine list avidly while the WINE STE stands by. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How does a '91 Meursault sound to everyone?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Great! Wendy hisses to her sister:

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Debbie, I told you not to do this.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: So he's a banker. He's also an opera buff and a gourmet.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: What is his political affiliation?

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: I have no idea! He was hard to wrangle for this dinner, a lot of women are after him. Honey, you've got to get back in the saddle.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: And roll in the hay? I love these dude ranch metaphors coming from a Connecticut matron.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Matron?! You could do with a hormone upgrade yourself. The sisters GIGGLE. ANGLE ON PETER'S PLATE - TWO HOURS LATER - the remains of fish and baby vegetables. PAN UP TO PETER in conference w the CHEF, whom he has summoned from the kitchen to find o the ingredients of the fish dish.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: White wine...lemon grass... cardamom?

dialogues.speaker: CHEF
dialogues.text: Ah, monsieur knows his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: And, let me take a wild guess, fennel seed? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Peter winks at Wendy, but she has a goblet of wine up to face.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF
dialogues.text: Very close. Anise.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You're a genius. He tries to slip the Chef a $100 bill.

dialogues.speaker: CHEF
dialogues.text: (embarrassed; retreats to kitchen) No, no. Please, enjoy.

dialogues.speaker: DEBBIE
dialogues.text: Peter, I don't know how you taste all that. Wendy, isn't he amazing?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: They're on dessert: profiteroles and sorbet. Wendy sticks with the wine. Peter leans closer to her, his tone intima

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: You have no idea how much I envy you. I'd love nothing more than to live a life of the mind.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I'd like something to take my mind off my mind.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: That's why I do yoga meditation. Tantric yoga, actually.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I do Ambien.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: (LAUGHS suavely) I knew you'd be witty. I love your reviews. By the end I always feel like I've read the book.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That accounts for the drop in sales. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Oh, I download ebooks all the time.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I like to hold a book in my hands.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Me too. When it's the right book. He guides a spoonful of sorbet to her lips. PETER (cont'd) Try the blood orange.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 98
dialogues.text: INT. WENDY'S BEDROOM - LATER вЂ” NIGHT 99

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON WENDY'S FACE - tense and miserable, as Peter thrusts i her slowly, methodically, punctuating each stroke with "Mmm"'s and "Ooo"'s and weird chortles, as if he's enjoyi good fondue.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Another position, same rhythm, same sounds. Now she's get sore.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Another position. She glances at the bedside clock: two a Now she's alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Aren't you ever going to come? He stops, smiling affably.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: No. I practise Tantric sex.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Can we stop, then?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Sure. He pulls out, lying beside her. She feels like she's been flattened by a truck. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: I was trying to make you come again.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I'm too tired. But thank you. (beat) So, when were you planning on coming?

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: Maybe next time. Or next time after that. What are you doing Thursday evening?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I have a driving lesson.

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: How about Sunday? I could come on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: PETER
dialogues.text: What's the matter? Peter raises up on his elbow, reads her face. PETER (cont'd) Oh. You have someone.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yes. I do.
99 100 Wendy's car slides cautiously into faster-moving TRAFFIC Upper Riverside Drive where it becomes four-lane.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You seem more comfortable now at higher speeds. She doesn't respond. She's withdrawn, depressed, her usua spikiness gone. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) It's time to put on your lights. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She finds the light dial. HEADLIGHTS GO ON. SHAFTS OF LIGHT from oncoming cars' HEADLIGHTS slide over their faces. DARWAN (cont'd) If the bright lights bother you, change the mirror. He flicks a switch on the rear-view mirror, darkening its reflection. She says nothing. DARWAN (cont'd) You're very quiet tonight.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Just focussing.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: That's good. Make a right. But he misses her combative energy. He steals a look at h sad profile, wonders what he could say to make her re-app ON WENDY - lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: TED, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The streetlamps look so shy in the twilight. WENDY'S POV (FANTASY) - PAN TO THE PASSENGER SEAT where T sits instead of Darwan. TED (cont'd) Like they've arrived too early at a party. And they stand outside, looking up at the shadows on the shade, deciding whether to go in.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It gets dark too fast for me these days. Does it make you sad, too?

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (nods; softly) Mm. We feel the end of life. The goodbye. ON WENDY - She turns to him in anguish. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: God, Ted. Will I ever be free of you? HER POV - Ted points ahead.

dialogues.speaker: TED
dialogues.text: (DARWAN'S VOICE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass him. WENDY - her attention goes back to the four-lane road.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Put on your signal. Give it the gas. WENDY'S POV THROUGH WINDSHIELD - gaining on the car in fr pulling to the left. As she passes, she sees TED IN THE C giving her a little wave. And then she's ahead of him, an he's gone. DARWAN (cont'd) Very good. You only need a little courage, and a little gas. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” NIGHT 101 Darwan is READING A POEM out loud, from the book he gave Jasleen. They are on the bed together.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: "A perfect Woman, nobly plann'd/ To warn, to comfort, and command;/ And yet a Spirit still, and bright/ With something of angelic light." (beat) Did you like that?

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: (lying) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Now you read this one to me. He chooses a page, hands her the book, and lays his head her lap with a contented sigh of expectation. He waits. ANGLE ON PAGE - A TEAR falls on the page of text. Darwan hears her SNIFFLE. He sits up. He sees her tear-fi eyes staring uncomprehendingly at the open book. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: DARWAN (cont'd) Don't tell me you can't read English.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: I am fourteen Baba [father] take me from school. 101

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: My God... He doesn't disguise his dismay. She flings the book again the wall.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: No thing I do is good for you!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Calm down --

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: (screams ) What you want?! What I do?! He loses his temper in turn.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You don't go out, you don't try to learn anything about America! You should be curious! You have a mind!

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: Like Wendy! She jumps off the bed, heading into the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy? Why are we talking about Wendy? He gets up to follow her. The bathroom door SLAMS. talks through the door. DARWAN (cont'd) Jasleen, please...tell me why you're so unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't never here! What you do all the time? Darwan (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I am working. I want a good life for our family. INSIDE BATHROOM - CONTINUOUS - Jasleen is huddled against door.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: You don't want with me. I am stupid. I cook too much ghee. EXT. DRIVING TEST SITE, BROOKLYN вЂ”- DAY 102 Darwan and Wendy are standing on the sidewalk in front of pool with kids in swimming in the background. There are a couple of CARS ahead of Wendy, everyone waiting for a dri test.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: If you accumulate more than thirty- five points, you fail. Now, what things in the test are worth fifteen points?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Parallel parking, broken U-turn...

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (a bundle of nerves) Going too fast.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Or too slow. What else?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Not observing right of way.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: If you fail any one of the fifteen- pointers, you automatically fail your test.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Are you sure I'm ready?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy, don't forget what I know: you are a very determined woman. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: My daughter calls me mujer de metal. Iron Woman.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Iron Woman. Does this mean you will do my shirts? They LAUGH. DARWAN (cont'd) Now tell me. What kind of car will you buy?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Something cheap. My divorce is costing a fortune.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Ready for you. Wendy is startled to realize the Examiner is behind her.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Oh my God...Darwan!

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: If you get nervous, just listen. You'll hear my voice telling you what to do.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINER
dialogues.text: Pull away from the curb, please. He pats her shoulder and withdraws: she's on her own. Fro Darwan's POV we see the student car pull away.

dialogues.speaker: EXAMINER
dialogues.text: (curtly) Start the car. Wendy's pulls out of the parking space and drives. 102 103 104  105 106 107 108 8/21/13 80. EXT. DRIVING TEST SITE вЂ”- MINUTES LATER вЂ” DAY 105

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DARWAN sees Wendy's car return and stop. The Examiner get out, advances to the next car. TRACKING WITH DARWAN toward the car. Wendy has her head b on the wheel, her fists pressing the sides her face. He quickens his step. WENDY looks at DARWAN with helpless despair.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 107
dialogues.text: INT. BAR вЂ”- LATER вЂ” LATE AFTERNOON 108 At a table in a dingy Irish bar, Wendy drains a glass of wine. Darwan sits opposite, correct and dignified, a mug coffee between his hands, ignoring the BARFLIES contemptuously staring at his turban and beard. Darwan, reading the sheet.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Sixty points? She lifts her head to face him.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I didn't taste it, Darwan. No beef stew. I went blank. He's disappointed, yet oddly relieved: now she will need again. WENDY (cont'd) Why did I ever think I could drive?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy, your next test will go better. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't belong on the road. I'm only trained to do one trick: ignore everything and everybody around me. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He glances 8/21/13. 81.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WENDY (cont'd) You know, there's a reason some people are alone: because they deserve to be. I ignored my husband. I ignored my daughter. No wonder he cheated on me. I mean, I openly cheated on them. Because my first and foremost love was for words. Words! I wrapped myself in them. And then I look at you. up. There's a thousand things in this world to divide two people, but you and Jasleen manage to be one spirit. Whew! (calls to WAITRESS) Miss! She gestures her glass for a refill, well on her way to a good drunk. Then she leans in closer. WENDY (cont'd) Just tell me: if she ever disappointed you, if she ever fell short in some way...would you ever cheat on her?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: No. I would never.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well, Darwan, you're a good man. You give me faith. He drops his eyes to his coffee. In the silence, the wait sets down Wendy's wine and departs. He doesn't look up. WENDY (cont'd) I don't even want this. She pushes her glass away abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (softly) I don't know how to talk to her. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Her turn to be silent. Almost afraid to breathe, she wait for more. DARWAN (cont'd) She's not educated. We don't like the same things at all. She's scared of America. She's scared of me. She hides. You know words, Wendy. What do I say? She thinks. When she speaks at last, it's from the bruise heart.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: That you'll never stop trying. That you'll fight for her. Every day, you'll try to cross the divide. Tell her she's worth it.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Is this what you wanted to hear from him? She SIGHS, averting her eyes to hold tears at bay.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Not words. You know what I miss? The way he touched my face. Just...holding my face between his two hands. As if I was treasure. They sit, as still as two people in prayer, allowing her sorrow to fill up the silence.

dialogues.speaker: I/E_ STUDENT CAR
dialogues.text: Darwan pulls the car up in front of Wendy's house.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (rummages in purse) Shit. Can you come inside? I left my checkbook at home.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You can pay me next time.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (gets out) No next time. I'm done with driving.  110 8/21/13 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy writes out a check while Darwan tries to persuade h

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You shouldn't give up. You only need a little more practise.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I don't have it in me, Darwan. I'm sorry. She hands him the check.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You make me say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (suddenly uncertain) I guess...yeah. He bows reluctantly, namaste, his palms together. WENDY (cont'd) Thank you. You did your best.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Not enough. A beat. He slowly brings his hands toward her. And gently touches the sides of her face. As if she is treasure. She releases a pained breath. She turns her face into his touch, leaning one cheek on his palm. He pulls his hands away. His face shows the struggle with DARWAN (cont'd) Goodbye, Wendy. Wendy watches as he leaves. FADE OUT. INT. BATHROOM, BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” DAY 111 Jasleen reaches opens the cabinet under the sink, takes o box of sanitary napkins she brought from India with Punja writing all over it. The box is empty. Her brow tightens with dismay.  112 8/21/13 84. INT. DUANE READE PHARMACY вЂ”- LATER вЂ” DAY 112 Jasleen wanders the long aisles of the drugstore, trying compare the pictures on her box to those on the shelves. MALE EMPLOYEE makes no attempt to help, looking at her Si clothes and veil with contempt. She rounds the corner, approaches a FEMALE EMPLOYEE and s her the box.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: Where is...?

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: I can't read that. A hand snatches the box away. It's another Sikh woman (MA 40ish).

dialogues.speaker: MATA
dialogues.text: You see the picture! You know what she wants!

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: No ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: MATA
dialogues.text: You work here and you don't know where is the sanitary napkin! Mata's raised voice gets the attention of the MANAGER, wh looks over.

dialogues.speaker: EMPLOYEE
dialogues.text: Aisle five. Mata grabs Jasleen's hand, pulling her toward the right aisle.

dialogues.speaker: MATA
dialogues.text: They're so rude here. You have to demand your respect in America! Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: Dadiala.

dialogues.speaker: MATA
dialogues.text: My uncle lives there! Why don't I see you at gurdwara, darling?  113 114 8/21/13 85. EXT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” LATER вЂ” MAGIC HOUR 113 Darwan pulls up in his taxi. He goes to his front door, t hesitates, surprised to hear WOMEN CHATTERING within. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ” CONTINUOUS - MAGIC HOUR 114 Darwan enters to find five SIKH WOMEN occupying the couch all YAKKING with Jasleen. He recognizes one.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Mata! Hello.

dialogues.speaker: MATA
dialogues.text: (re: Jasleen) Darwan Singh! Why do you shut up this pearl in the house?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (on the spot; smiles) I assure you she's free to go anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MATA
dialogues.text: (to Jasleen) What a husband! Leaving you alone all the time. Don't worry, darling, we make our own fun here, we don't need him. Jasleen casts an anxious look at Darwan, gets up to go to kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: I make dinner.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Never mind. Enjoy your new friends. (goes to door) I'll pick up something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: SIKH WOMAN
dialogues.text: (calls after him) That's right, leave her to us. You won't recognize her when we're done with her! The women HOOT with laughter. Jasleen grins.  8/21/13 86. INT. WENDY'S NEW APARTMENT вЂ” DAY 115 PANNING OVER PACKING CARTONS - their flaps open, revealin hundreds of BOOKS waiting to be put on shelves. ANOTHER ANGLE - TASHA helps Wendy unpack in her new, bare apartment. The dark, hermetic burrow of her old townhouse been replaced by open space and tall windows.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Whew! There's so much...stuff.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Believe me, I threw out tons. Wendy puts her arm around her daughter. WENDY (cont'd) Bless you for helping. But hadn't you better get on the road? It's a long drive.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Mom...I think I won't go back. (off Wendy's surprise) I love farming but...mainly I wanted to be close to this guy, and then he suddenly decided to go back to Dartmouth, and so now I'm alone and all the other kids are gone...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: So - what? You want to go back to school, too? Isn't it too late for the semester?

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Yeah...Maybe I won't go back at all. Tasha's voice catches; tears in her eyes; swallows a sob. TASHA (cont'd) I'm just so embarrassed...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (embraces her) Baby...

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Can I stay here with you? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (gently) Tasha. No. And not because I wouldn't love it. But if you move in here it will be in a spirit of failure. And that is deadly. Finish this thing out. Go back to Vermont and harvest your ass off. Make it a triumph. Tasha nods, sniffing back tears.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Back to the earth.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Yeah, I think so.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: Okay. She hugs her mother again, not wanting to let go.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I'll visit you. I promise.

dialogues.speaker: TASHA
dialogues.text: But it's so far.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I will find a way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WENDY is at her desk on the phone speaking to DARWAN.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It's me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendy drives through Brooklyn with Darwan by her side. Th conversation in the following sequence is punctuated by l easy silences: they are as comfortable together as an old married couple.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: How is Jasleen?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: She's very busy. She goes to school now, taking classes... They drive around Fort Tryon Park where the leaves are changing in the amber September sun...

dialogues.speaker: WENDY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who do you think will win the World Series?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, Indians don't know baseball. Cricket's our game. Passing through Grand Army Plaza, with its bronze Civil W statue of General Sherman... DARWAN (cont'd) How do you like your new apartment?

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It's an adjustment. I'm tasting it. They exchange smiles. LATER - Passing through Carroll Gardens, with its affluen homes guarded by elaborate wrought-iron gates... ...Williamsburg waterfront, with its decaying artist- inhabited buildings and water taxis... WENDY (cont'd) You're so quiet.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You're not doing anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: I/E. DRIVING TEST SITE
dialogues.text: Darwan paces alone, shivering a little in the fall air. H keeps stopping to peer anxiously down the street. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He buys coffee from a STREET VENDOR. Suddenly he sees the student car returning with Wendy at wheel. The TEST EXAMINER (#2) is in the passenger seat be her. Abandoning the coffee and his money with the Vendor, Darw breaks into a run... WIDE ANGLE - Examiner #2 emerges from the passenger side, striding away with her clipboard. As Darwan reaches the c Wendy jumps from the car and flings her arms around him w a little SHRIEK of victory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan drives through Brooklyn, taking Wendy back to Manhattan. She's on her cell phone to Tasha.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (into phone) Sweetie, I got it!...Yes!...1I wasn't as nervous this time...Soon, I hope. When are the leaves turning up there? I've always wanted to see that!... As her CONVERSATION FADES we PAN TO DARWAN'S FACE: conflicted, as their relationship draws to a close. Suddenly Wendy pokes his arm, breaking his trance. WENDY (cont'd) Park here! She's pointing gaily to a CAR DEALERSHIP. EXT. PARKING LOT, CAR DEALERSHIP вЂ”- LATER вЂ” DAY 120 A SALESMAN stands with Darwan and Wendy looking at a RED COMPACT car.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: It's a good price.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: You can drive it off the lot today, if the color's okay with you.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I never thought of red, but...? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: She turns to Darwan.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Red is happy. It's what the bride wears to the wedding in India.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: But what does it say about me? I'm a hot little number? Hussy on board?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: It says... He leans in and whispers: DARWAN (cont'd) "Don't fuck with me." They both break up GIGGLING, their heads together. The Salesman eyes them, thinking they are certainly the oddes couple he's seen in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Salesman prepares the paperwork at his desk. Darwan a Wendy sit opposite.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: So, who is purchasing the vehicle, you or your wife?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: (taken aback) She's -- she's not my wife.

dialogues.speaker: SALESMAN
dialogues.text: But whose name will the car be under, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Really, we are not together.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: (teasing) Honey, it's okay. (to Salesman) I'm buying it. 120 121  122 8/21/13 91. EXT. PARKING LOT, CAR DEALERSHIP - LATER вЂ”- LATE AFTERN The salesman leads them back to the little red car and ceremoniously hands Wendy her new car keys. Darwan CLAPS applause. Wendy beams. It's like a birthday. The Salesman returns inside. Wendy opens her car door.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Wait. How do I get home?

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: You can follow me to the bridge. She still doesn't get in. They're both reluctant, now tha this moment is here.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Darwan...Thank you. (smiles) I'll be hearing your voice in my head for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: That would please me.

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: Well...Here goes! She turns to climb inside her new car. His formality crumbles; he holds her back; words rush from him heedless he knows he's begging but can't stop himself:

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy -- could we go somewhere? We can celebrate, have dinner -- please -- She's already shaking her head. DARWAN (cont'd) Or have coffee some time, just to chat --

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I can't. It costs her to refuse him, and her eyes show her regret.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: I want to see you again. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: I know. She quickly wraps her arms around his neck, hugging him close. His heart opens wide and he presses himself to her Then she pulls away. WENDY (cont'd) The trouble is...

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: What? Why? She leans in and gives him a soft kiss on the cheek. Then

dialogues.speaker: WENDY
dialogues.text: .В«..You're a good man. (smiles) You're my faith. He looks on forlornly as she gets into her new car, puts key in the ignition.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Wendy. She looks up. DARWAN (cont'd) (his voice rough with emotion) Seat belt first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little red car follows the student car toward the Brooklyn Bridge. The Student Car turns to go to Queens as the little red c goes over the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwan enters. There's a crowd, mostly men arrived after work. Darwan sees an open spot next to a woman. He makes move toward it, then stops short. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: He realizes it's Jasleen. Her eyes are downcast in prayer her lips moving. He is struck by the simple, heartfelt devotion in her face. An image out of the old country. He retreats so she won't see him. INT. BASEMENT APARTMENT вЂ”- LATER вЂ” NIGHTFALL 126

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jasleen enters, her arms of with school books and grocery bags. She stops short, seeing Darwan seated on the bed. He's very still, just looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: (much improved English) Darwan, I didn't expect you. Something in his manner makes her put down her bags and s quickly beside him.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Jasleen...Maybe I will not work at night anymore. Would you like that?

dialogues.speaker: JASLEEN
dialogues.text: Oh, yes! A beat. He drops his eyes, feeling his awkwardness, his stubborn formality. He must gather his courage to "cross divide," as Wendy would say. JASLEEN (cont'd) Darwan? He looks up. JASLEEN (cont'd) If you have more time now... can you teach me to drive? He lights up. Gazing at her with a warmth and a need she hasn't see before, he stretches his hand to her face.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN
dialogues.text: Yes. His fingers touch her cheek tenderly, as if she was treas Her dark eyes shine, and she leans her face gratefully in his palm...
EXT. WENDY'S APARTMENT BUILDING вЂ” DAY 127

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON CAR TRUNK OPENING. The DOORMAN places her LUGGAG inside. INT. WENDY'S NEW CAR вЂ”- DAY 128 HER NEW KEY ENTERS THE IGNITION, turning... INT. MOVING CAR вЂ”- LATER вЂ” DAY 129 Wendy drives slowly, with growing confidence, through the York streets. HER EYES flicker up, down, side to side, using the mirror reading the signs, seeing the whole picture. FANTASY: Magically, more travellers materialize all aroun if accompanying and escorting her into the traffic flow: TAXI, a VAN, a TEENAGER ON A SCOOTER, a PEDI-CAB, a MOTORCYCLIST, a PUSHCART VENDOR, a BICYCLE MESSENGER, a mighty river of travellers; all carried, like her, into t uncharted horizon... And as far as she can see ahead, all the TRAFFIC LIGHTS A GREEN.

dialogues.speaker: DARWAN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Go on, Wendy. You have the light. WENDY takes a DEEP BREATH. HER FOOT PRESSES THE ACCELERATOR DEEPER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WENDY'S CAR skims up a two-lane road, entering the arches dazzling AUTUMN FOLIAGE: LEAVES turning scarlet, saffron, orange, and crimson, against the turquoise sky, like the colors of a Punjabi wedding. FADE OUT.
